body: A cheery holiday card from Tati and Gerry at Ansonia Records rests on the counter of Manny Rivera's Brooklyn music store, hidden behind a pile of compact discs, domino sets and assorted tropical knick-knacks. It's a nice, personal touch in a business that has long since lost it. Forty two years ago - when Manny was born into the retail record
title: CITY ROOM; A Brooklyn Music Store Resolves to Adapt

body: The chief executive of a troubled Brooklyn hospital has been abruptly dismissed, less than a month after a task force set up by the administration of Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo outlined a plan to carry out a major reorganization of how hospital care is delivered in Brooklyn. Soon after the dismissal of the chief executive, Rajiv Garg, a member of the
title: Abrupt Shift In Leadership At a Hospital

title: Recent Lease

body: Aristotle believed circular motion to be a distinguishing characteristic of perfection. If you have ever seen a world-class runner cruise around a track, you may well agree that a body curving in motion is a sight of beauty. On a snowy day in late October, Luis Galvan was not particularly quick or light as he trudged around the otherwise deserted
title: Where Lives Overlap

body: WHEN Loren Munk began furtively filming New York City gallery and museum openings in 2006 -- ''working undercover,'' as he put it -- he was regularly kicked out by security guards and threatened with legal action for copyright infringement. Since then, however, Mr. Munk's camera has become a welcome guest, and using the alias James Kalm, he has
title: Via YouTube, Leading Tours of the City's Art Scene

body: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo is enjoying his Emperor Hadrian moment. His many legislative victories come accompanied by festive celebrations and loud huzzahs. So Maria Bartiromo, the CNBC anchor, travels to Albany to preside over a joyous allocation of money for regional economic development. So, in the wake of his income tax deal, senators and assemblymen
title: GOTHAM; Amid Paeans to Cuomo, Some Less Lofty Notes

body: Brad Hunstable started Ustream, an online video platform, with a fellow West Point graduate back in 2007 to help American troops overseas communicate with multiple friends and family members at the same time. It was not long before its uses extended well beyond the military. Celebrities, politicians and organizers of events like rock concerts and
title: Occupy Video Showcases Live Streaming

body: Long Island and three struggling upstate regions were the big winners Thursday in a competition for $785 million in one of Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo's signature development initiatives. In a session that resembled a pep rally, the state awarded more than $100 million each to four regions: Long Island; central New York, with its hub in Syracuse; western
title: Long Island Gets Big Grant In Cuomo's Competition

body: Alexander Garvin, natty in bowtie and jacket, watched commuters hustle through the gray, sunken concrete plaza at Citigroup Center on Lexington Avenue. Across 53rd Street, in the fading afternoon light, more New Yorkers ducked into a faceless subway kiosk on the triangular patch of wind-swept sidewalk -- ostensibly a second public plaza -- that
title: Treasuring Urban Oases

Boyland Jr. was indicted for a second time, accused again of soliciting bribes in exchange for official favors -- in part to pay his legal fees from the first trial -- longtime residents of Brownsville, one of Brooklyn's most
title: A Lawmaker Back in Trouble, in a District That Knows Despair

body: The New York State health commissioner should be given sweeping new powers to replace the executives and board members of private hospitals, a group appointed by Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo recommended Monday in a report on how to restructure Brooklyn's failing hospitals and health system. The report calls for legislation to provide such authority ''not
title: Panel Urges Sharp Change For Hospitals In Brooklyn

body: STEINBERG--Natalie, 88 years old, died on November 24, 2011. Beloved wife of the late Bernard. Devoted and cherished mother of Leigh, Ellen and the late Neil Steinberg. Adored grandmother of Brandon, Haley and Ashley Finkelstein. Dedicated teacher to many students in Bushwick, Brooklyn. Her love for life and family will never be forgotten.
title: Paid Notice: Deaths STEINBERG, NATALIE

body: THE cemeteries that line southern Queens have moonlighted for decades, standing as a natural fence around Glendale, a subdued working- and middle-class neighborhood. They helped keep the neighborhood relatively isolated. (The lack of a subway or commuter train station helped, too.) And that was not all bad. ''For a long time,'' said Kathy Masi, a
title: LIVING IN | GLENDALE, QUEENS; Tucked Away and Neatly Tricked Out

body: Social media has played a vital role in the Occupy Wall Street movement since it began as a Twitter experiment in July, when the anticonsumerism magazine Adbusters posted a suggestion for a Sept. 17 march in Lower Manhattan. And over the last two months, protesters used cellphones and social sites like Twitter, Facebook and YouTube to spread their
title: Protesters Look for Ways to Feed the Web

body: In a darkened theater a platform suspended from the ceiling sways back and forth above a sea of empty liquor bottles. Lying prostrate on it, balding and disheveled in a rumpled tie and jacket, is Donny, wrestling with a hangover of Olympian proportions. Or maybe it's just the result of a fall he has taken. Whichever, he can barely stand. Donny is
title: THEATER REVIEW | '---- DONE BROKE'; Alcohol Applied Liberally To a Bitterly Busted Life

body: When the pain in his groin was too great to bear, Ralph Hutchins, who works as a mover, headed to the crowded emergency room at the nearest hospital one recent Tuesday, his life at risk. Tanya Boynton, a mother of four who works 12-hour shifts, hobbled into another emergency room from a homeless shelter, afraid illness would end her job. They
title: Caring for Poor In Harsh Focus As Hospitals Ail

body: The view from the penthouse atop 144 North Eighth Street in Williamsburg, Brooklyn -- the much-loathed ''finger building'' that by virtue of a fluke of timing and rezoning is far taller than its neighbors -- goes on for miles. Looming high above the converted warehouses, vinyl-sided frame buildings and brick town houses of the area, the apartment,
title: THE APPRAISAL; Tower Has Its Own Lawn, But Neighbors Still Look For Their Open Space

body: As dusk fell, a woman, head to toe in black, bounded down the sidewalk, with a leash in one hand and a baby tucked against her chest. By the curb, two men in suits loudly debated the stock market. And at a Mexican bistro, patrons sipped Chardonnay from stemless glasses under graffiti framed as art. Ordinary stuff, maybe, for many New York
title: 26.2 Miles of Change

body: As the cold, heavy snow pelted a disbelieving city last Saturday, a landscaping crew -- thoroughly chilled after hours spent working outside a church in the Bronx -- loaded their equipment into two trucks and headed back to Queens, ready to call it an early day. In the back of one, surrounded by the tools of the trade, Jorge Perez and his cousin
title: Worker Dies Using Lawn Mower for Warmth

body: MARNI Kotak would not give birth in just any art gallery. ''I had to trust the gallerists on an intuitive level,'' she said the other day. ''And the space had to be a safe and comfortable environment. I mean, I couldn't imagine giving birth in a big white-box gallery in Chelsea.'' Ms. Kotak, 36, a performance artist, found what she was looking for
title: For a Gallery at the Edge, Fame Is Born Tuesday

body: WITH his manly stubble, flannel shirt and skinny black jeans, Brandon Flowers looks every bit the hipster front man for his rock band, the Killers. With songs about drowning one's sorrows in bourbon or exploring the seedy underbelly of his hometown, Las Vegas, Mr. Flowers has sold more than 15 million records worldwide. In the past, he has been
title: To Be Young, Hip and Mormon

body: Only one in four students who enter high school in New York City are ready for college after four years, and less than half enroll, according to the A-through-F high school report cards released on Monday. Those numbers, included for the first time in the report cards, confirmed what the state suggested several months ago: the city still has a long
title: College Readiness Lacking, Reports Show

body: ON a trip to an indie bookstore in Brooklyn in the summer, I came across a curious creation: a small, black-and-white publication that consisted entirely of snapshots of Lindsay Lohan, known for her movie roles in ''Mean Girls'' and ''The Parent Trap,'' and, more recently, for her well-publicized courtroom appearances. This print tribute to Ms.
title: PING; Raised on the Web, But Liking a Little Ink

body: THE restaurant was Chinese in theory, with Continental accents, and wedged into a basement in Midtown. There was foie gras in the dumplings. The music was the sort one hears in elevators in cities far from home. One of my guests happened to be a dead ringer for the actor Matthew Broderick. ''I have waited on you many times,'' the waiter said to
title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK; Pleasure to Dine With You

body: Timothy Haskell, a designer of haunted houses, scares people for a living. This season he has created two: Nightmare: Z-Day, a zombie playhouse in the Bronx, running until Halloween, and Nightmare: Fairy Tales, on the Lower East Side, through Nov. 5. Mr. Haskell, 37, whose background is in Off Broadway theater, lives in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, with
title: SUNDAY ROUTINE | TIMOTHY HASKELL; Far From His Usual Haunts

body: Buoyed by the longevity of the Occupy Wall Street encampment in Manhattan, a wave of protests swept across Asia, the Americas and Europe on Saturday, with hundreds and in some cases thousands of people expressing discontent with the economic tides in marches, rallies and occasional clashes with the police. In Rome, a rally thick with tension spread
geo_facet: FAR EAST, SOUTH AND SOUTHEAST ASIA AND PACIFIC AREAS
title: Rallies Across the Globe Protest Economic Policies

body: ''The buses?'' said Javier Valdés. ''I have 20, in total.'' He checked a list, then corrected himself. ''Sorry,'' he said. ''Twenty-one.'' On Wednesday morning, those buses will pick up about 1,000 people from Brooklyn, Staten Island and Queens and drop them at Cadman Plaza for a march across the Brooklyn Bridge. title: ABOUT NEW YORK; In This Case, A Protest With Focus

body: For Cosmo Baker, a D.J., music producer and writer, Sundays are a chance to wind down from traveling -- coming trips include ones to South Africa and Dubai -- and late-night Saturdays, while relaxing and exploring the city. Mr. Baker, 37, lives with his wife, Sydney Peck, a lawyer, in Fort Greene, Brooklyn. EMILY MARETSKY LATE NIGHT, EARLY MORNING
title: SUNDAY ROUTINE | COSMO BAKER; A Night Owl Explores by Day

body: The pink slips have gone out, and if no deal is reached by Friday, 716 of New York City's lowest-paid workers -- school aides, parent coordinators and other members of school support staffs -- will lose their jobs, the latest victims of budget cuts to the public schools. Nearly 350 schools will be affected, in a scattered pattern, according to a
title: School Layoffs About to Fall Heaviest On the Poorest and Most Struggling

body: A man named Hero was here. So was Germ. There was the waitress from the dim sum restaurant in Evanston, Ill. And the liquor store worker. The Google consultant. The circus performer. The Brooklyn nanny. The hodgepodge Lower Manhattan encampment known as Occupy Wall Street has no appointed leaders, no expiration date for its rabble-rousing stay and
title: Wall Street Occupiers, Protesting Till Whenever

body: Though Greg Fox isn't a singer, he has been the lungs of the sort-of-metal band Liturgy, from Brooklyn. His drumming often comes in blast-beats, long runs of eighth notes played on snare and cymbal and kick drum, all of them stressed. His playing, like that of Keith Moon and Tony Williams, isn't just a bottom layer, but a dramatic arc that keeps
title: MUSIC REVIEW; Investigations Into the Aggressive Use of Beats

body: In 1983, a police officer from Bushwick with scars from six gunshot wounds from his right shoulder to his left hip was lucky to be alive, and he darn well knew it, so he put in his papers after 22 years on the job. In the next neighborhood over, Greenpoint, an immigrant jeweler arrived that year, eager to work. They were both Polish, both Brooklyn
title: CRIME SCENE; A Career Criminal's Prints Link Two Lives Upended Decades Apart

body: The inbox on Mr. Critic's computer beeped and booped with questions this week about where to eat with brothers and wives, about where to eat on an Upper East Side art crawl, and about where to eat after a wedding in Central Park. I did my best to answer. In October I take my leave of this job to take on new duties at The New York Times. (Hey, Mr.
title: HEY, MR. CRITIC; A Four-Star for a Special Visit

body: From her bare kitchen window, Denise Urquidez can see the big grassy backyard that became a haven for her two young sons. And she wonders. The curtains are packed away along with the Transformers that had decorated her boys' room. Ms. Urquidez is waiting to move, leaving her tiny two-bedroom in a salmon stucco three-story building on the edge of
title: Staying With Children, And Out of Prison

body: The Democratic machine whirred and then roared in northern Brooklyn on Tuesday, churning out a significant victory for Rafael L. Espinal in a fiercely contested three-way race for the 54th State Assembly District seat. Mr. Espinal, 27, the chief of staff for City Councilman Erik Martin Dilan and the chosen candidate of the Brooklyn party chairman,
title: Democratic Party Pick Wins Brooklyn Race

body: Man Forever, a five-piece band, was making some decidedly unmarketable noise. Two drummers sat on either side of a snare drum, rolling out an undercurrent of cadences, while an organist with wild hair played endlessly sustained dissonant chords, and the bass and guitar thrummed muddy harmonies that fed back on themselves. The effect was of a
title: Underground Musicians Lose a Haven

body: ON most days, Katlyn Hershman can be found smeared with grease, plying her skills as a mechanic at Bike Works NYC, a shop on the Lower East Side. When she answers the store phone, though, all that toil and expertise can suddenly seem invisible. ''Guys automatically ask for the mechanic,'' she said. ''But I don't really take it personally.'' Ms.
title: SPOKES; Women With Wrenches

''I can assure you if you are for workers' rights, a higher minimum wage, good schools and justice in our community, I'm your candidate,'' said Jesus Gonzalez,
title: Special Election In Brooklyn Could Upset Politics as Usual

body: On Thursday, New York City will burn to the ground. Preposterous? Not if you happen to be in the Nevada desert, outside Reno. There you can watch the city being burned. In effigy. That effigy is a structure that includes MetroCards, re-creations of four city bridges and a 20-foot-wide map of the subway -- without the G train. Before it combusts, it
title: Building New York Up, Only to Set It on Fire in the Nevada Desert

body: THE waiter was on his second shirt. It was early evening on a deep-summer Sunday in Bushwick, Brooklyn, in the dining room of Roberta's, one of the more extraordinary restaurants in the United States. Rock music throbbed just loudly enough to diminish the poppy noise of a large dance party outside in the garden where the restaurant grows its herbs
title: RESTAURANT REVIEW; Making The Most Of a Stove

body: To drive down Kings Highway in East Flatbush is to pass block after block of near-identical brick homes, neat gardens, statuary and ironwork. Yet if you live on the road's north side, in Councilman Jumaane D. Williams's district, the leader of the City Council allocates about $2.50 per resident each year in discretionary spending. If you live on
title: GOTHAM; A Council Speaker Who Tightens the Purse Strings on Dissent

body: Adam Distenfeld was driving by a construction pit on Nostrand Avenue in Brooklyn a few weeks ago and couldn't resist. Mr. Distenfeld, 48, is a sculptor who prefers granite gneiss -- the banded metamorphic rock found beneath swaths of New York City -- and in the Nostrand pit he saw a boulder of it. He had never seen one larger. He needed it. But you
title: CITY ROOM; A Heavy Nuisance Becomes a Sculptor's Niche

body: Mr. Jungreis, 41, is the president of the Rosewood Realty Group, a boutique commercial real estate brokerage firm that focuses on sales of multifamily, retail and office properties largely in the outer boroughs. The company also does business in Manhattan and New Jersey. Mr. Jungreis started the company with his cousin David Berger in 2007. Q
title: SQUARE FEET | THE 30-MINUTE INTERVIEW; Aaron Jungreis

body: Millerton, N.Y. FROM the venerable general store his grandparents opened in 1919, where you can get hunting knives, cigars, worms, khaki pants and copies of Vogue, Phil Terni has watched Dutchess County's passing parade for most of his 68 years. The store has seen celebrated customers -- Babe Ruth, Ava Gardner, Artie Shaw, Ruth Bader Ginsburg --
title: Williamsburg on the Hudson

body: Relations between Maria de los Santos and the landlord of her railroad apartment in Bushwick, Brooklyn, soured after she filed a complaint in 2007 over lack of heat. But they worsened, she said, after she discovered she had been overcharged in rent and appealed to the state housing agency for help. Ms. de los Santos said the agency did not process
title: Complaints to State of Illegal Rents Often Languish, Advocacy Group Says

body: Mark Dunlea and his wife, Judith A. Enck, moved to Brooklyn from upstate New York two years ago. Last March, they breached the blurry Clinton Hill border to buy an apartment in a four-story condominium that had replaced an abandoned warehouse in Bedford-Stuyvesant. The couple say they do not feel like pioneers in the gentrification of
title: A Striking Evolution in Bedford-Stuyvesant as the White Population Soars

title: Calendar

body: The federal government has cited a tortilla company in Brooklyn for violations carrying fines totaling over $62,000 after an investigation into the death of a worker who fell into an industrial mixing machine at its factory, officials said Friday. The most serious violation involved the failure of the company, Tortilleria Chinantla, to install a
title: Safety Agency Cites Tortilla Company Where Worker Died

body: A stream of hospital administrators, a state assemblyman, doctors and advocates for immigrants took the microphone at a sometimes raucous hearing in Downtown Brooklyn on Thursday to plead with state officials not to close, merge or shrink troubled hospitals in the borough. The advocates identified at least 5 of the 17 hospitals in the borough --
title: Hospitals In Brooklyn Defended At Hearing

body: Images of 9/11 are embedded in our visual memory: the airplanes flying into the twin towers; the towers crumbling; the fleeing people; the stark Manhattan skyline when it was over. As the 10th anniversary approaches, MoMA PS1 plans to remember the attacks, but not in the obvious way. Rather than exploring how art has evolved over the past decade or
title: INSIDE ART; MoMA PS1 Plans 9/11 Exhibition

body: When Luke Babcock Keller, 25, left Chicago to join his girlfriend in New York last August, he had aspirations to act and to produce videos and a bachelor's degree in communications from DePaul University, but he didn't have a job. With his nest egg running on empty, he contacted a temp agency and was sent to IceStone, a manufacturer of countertop
title: ENTRY LEVEL; After Dreams of Acting, an Unexpected Role

body: When Lisa Marion's roommates moved out of her apartment in Toronto in February, she scrambled to find replacements. But instead of finding one or two, she found 30. Ms. Marion, 26, has been using Airbnb, a Web site that streamlines the process of renting out her extra bedrooms to travelers. The service has unexpectedly turned her into a
title: Room to Let, via the Web

body: THE project earned him an easy A. ''I was in seventh or eighth grade, and we were asked to do a little genealogy,'' recalled Andrew Van Dusen, now a 47-year-old real estate broker specializing in Brownstone Brooklyn. title: IN THE FAMILY; The Van Dusens Of New Amsterdam

body: Pop Ben Ratliff JAMES FALZONE is a tremendously likable, alert, no-nonsense improvising clarinetist from Chicago. He comes for a rare New York visit this week, and plays three nights in a row; see him while you can. Mr. Falzone's music is thoughtful and often quiescent, but he can play hard to the breaking point. He likes history, but he's not only
title: THE WEEK AHEAD | JULY 24-JULY 30

body: THE streets of New York are paved with gold, and Kenny Lao was out there on a recent morning, prospecting. ''I'm not feeling this block: too many parking lots, too many loading docks, kind of dead,'' he said as he drove his lumbering red, white and blue Rickshaw Dumpling Truck on 54th Street, east of Broadway, hunting for a new parking spot. Then,
title: Looking to Park? So Is Your Lunch

body: THIS sprawling neighborhood in northern Brooklyn was one of the borough's first European settlements, and has been known for many things over its long history: for its farms, then for its breweries and factories, then for the blight and crime that descended in the decades after those employers closed. Pages from that history are always on display
title: LIVING IN | BUSHWICK, BROOKLYN; The Vanguard Alights

body: Since 2009, unemployment among recent college graduates has risen, while starting salaries have fallen. The median student debt load for those who graduated from 2006 to 2010 is $20,000. Not surprisingly, 40 percent of 20-somethings move back in with their parents at least once. Here are some dispatches from the home front. My Tragic Starring Role
title: TOWNIES; Growing Up, Then Going Home

title: UP CLOSE; Becoming One Of the 'Relevant'

title: THEATER REVIEW | 'DEATH VALLEY'; The Undead Are Uneasy in the Untamed West

title: For Many Immigrants, Marriage Vote Resonates

Young people sat on lumpy couches, barely talking to one another, lost in their own reveries. Onstage a series of performers came and went, though at any given time there were as many people smoking and chatting on the
title: MUSIC REVIEW; Keyboard Speaks Louder Than a Microphone

body: BARUCH HERZFELD, a landlord in Brooklyn, sometimes finds himself unsure about a potential tenant. Because his buildings are in neighborhoods like Bushwick and Bedford-Stuyvesant, which are frequented by artistic and creative workers, a number of his applicants have questionable credit or spotty incomes. But rather than reject them out of hand, Mr.
title: Bad Credit, But Good Vibes

body: WHEN the sun glares down on the city, New Yorkers of means flee for the beach. Matt Kaye, a bar manager and D.J. who lives in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, was such a refugee. He sat outside Rippers, a new grass-fed-burger shack that opened over the Memorial Day weekend, sipping an iced coffee. In the distance, a pod of surfers bobbed in the water,
title: Taking the A Train to Summer

body: The blue-and-white ferry nudged up to the dock at East 34th Street on Monday morning and deposited its cargo: about 70 commuters, their business suits unmoved by the wind, happy to have made it from Brooklyn to Manhattan in less time than it can take to catch an L train at rush hour. ''What is this? Twenty minutes?'' José Luis Coirolo, a financial
title: East River Ferry Service, With 7 Stops, Starts Run

body: The first performances of Trisha Brown's ''Roof Piece'' took place on rooftops from 53 Wooster Street to 381 Lafayette Street in Manhattan, and even though I wasn't there, a remarkable photograph from 1971 has always made me feel otherwise. In Babette Mangolte's black-and-white image a dancer stands in the foreground. Leaning forward, one knee bent
title: DANCE REVIEW; Red Chain Reactions Against the Sky

body: ON a recent Sunday, Williamsburg, Brooklyn, was bustling at midday. You couldn't move on the main drag of Bedford Avenue, between the people milling, the sidewalk vendors selling, and the groups jockeying for position in the sport of brunch. Day-trippers from Manhattan were headed for Smorgasburg, the food extension of the Brooklyn Flea; a line had
title: BLOCK BY BLOCK | GRAND STREET, WILLIAMSBURG; Perpendicular to Brunch

body: For decades now, the pattern has been the same: New York City factories fall prey to the hunger for offbeat places to live, and once-gritty industrial neighborhoods like SoHo, TriBeCa, Dumbo and the meatpacking district are transformed into enviable residential enclaves. But in each evolution, there is a fraught, in-between moment when the factory
title: GREENPOINT JOURNAL; A Slaughterhouse in Brooklyn, and Misery Next Door

body: In its brief, half-decade history, the Bushwick Open Studios festival has earned a reputation as an eclectic, unpredictable entree into the underground Brooklyn arts scene, replete with cabarets, outre costumes, and free exhibitions from hundreds of local artists. The festival has also become known for something else: poor subway service. In three
title: CITY ROOM; L Train's Out Again? Must Be Arts Show Weekend

body: When you are a writer, even Sunday is a workday. J. Courtney Sullivan, 29, whose second novel, ''Maine,'' due out next month from Knopf, is expected to be one of the major beach reads of the summer, usually goes to the Brooklyn Writers Space at some point during the day. Still, she makes time for walks with her puppy, for breakfasts fit for a
title: SUNDAY ROUTINE | J. COURTNEY SULLIVAN; Brunch and TV, but Still a Workday

body: ''ALWAYS crazy here,'' Ernie Wong was saying. It's not just the constant ring-ring of the land lines. There's the smash-bash of stainless steel resisting ball-peen hammers. The wheeeen of the polishers smoothing steel burrs. The shoooosss of the welding sparks. Not to mention Mr. Wong's mother, Sylvia, schmoozing on the cellphone in Shanghainese
title: Artistry on Wheels

body: This just in: Lt. M. K. Schwenk's first name was Milton, not Melton, as his obituary said. In 1899. His great-nephew, Dr. Daniel A. F. Schwenk, a retired dentist from Walpole, N.H., wrote to The Times last month, pointing out what he said were several errors in the 264-word obituary published on June 29, 1899. ''It's a tad late'' to bring them up,
title: CITY ROOM; Correction: An Obituary In 1899 Misstated ...

body: The musical and experimental theater -- the two theatrical forms in which New York is arguably the world leader -- have more in common than you might think. Currently dominated by technologically sophisticated, rigorously precise and highly self-aware productions, they are both generally more visceral than intellectual. And when something goes
title: THEATER REVIEW | 'HERE AT HOME'; Swapping War Stories Outside a Wal-Mart

body: IN a city obsessed with the shiny and novel, Gotham Bar and Grill is an outlier. Open since 1984, it celebrates stability and excellence, perhaps even opulence. Fabric chandeliers billow beneath soaring ceilings. Elaborate flowers are everywhere. People dress for dinner and are escorted past marvelous photographs on the way to their tables. It is
title: RESTAURANT REVIEW; An American Classic With Nods to Now

body: Two people were killed on Friday night when a fast-moving fire engulfed the top floor of a building in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn, the authorities said. The fire began shortly after 9 p.m. at 16 Covert Street, in a three-story row house with furnished rooms occupied primarily by older men, neighbors said. The blaze grew rapidly, gutting the
title: Two Are Dead After a Fire in Brooklyn

body: An undercover officer posing as a gun buyer shot and killed a gun trafficker in Brooklyn on Wednesday night after the man pointed a gun at him, the police said. The shooting took place shortly before 8 p.m. in the Bushwick neighborhood, as the undercover officer was trying to buy six handguns from a man on the ground floor of 193 Knickerbocker
title: Undercover Officer Kills Gun Trafficker in Brooklyn, Police Say

title: ART IN REVIEW; Matthew Miller: 'the magic black of an open barn door on a really sunny summer day, when you just cannot see into it'

body: It's no secret that I love pigeons. They have been a fascination of mine since I was a young boy, and they continue to bring me great peace even now. People are curious as to why I have such great affection for them. The answer is simple. It's because they aren't difficult to understand. Unlike human beings that have the capacity to manipulate and
title: CITY ROOM; Mike Tyson on His Eternally Loyal Friend, the Pigeon

body: RANDY WEINER, the playwright and theater producer, is terrified of boring his audiences. So he was noticeably nervous before a new production of his play ''Caligula Maximus,'' a campy extravaganza that made its debut in early April at the House of Yes in Bushwick, Brooklyn. He needn't have worried. The show's male go-go dancers, topless aerialists
title: UP CLOSE; He Puts the Maximus in the Circus

body: The driver of a New York City Sanitation truck was arrested and charged with driving that truck while intoxicated early Tuesday evening, the police said. He was driving it on the wrong side of the road on Grand Street in Bushwick, Brooklyn, when he crashed into a Hyundai Elantra. The driver of the Hyundai, who is 34, and a man sitting in the
title: After Crash, Sanitation Driver Faces D.U.I. Charge

body: The football players huddled on the sideline in the fading sunlight. Several looked out from under silver helmets at their 6-foot-3, 310-pound coach, Darnell Stapleton, in a gray sweatshirt with ''Pittsburgh Steelers'' emblazoned on the front. ''Let's go out there and get better,'' he said before sending the women of the New York Sharks out to run
title: Former Steeler Starts Over as a Women's Coach

body: The woman stared up in shock at the scorched remains of her Brooklyn apartment on Tuesday morning, a day after a fire there killed two of her daughters and her husband. She was hoping for a small piece of salvation. Then, in a third-floor window, a worker from the city's Buildings Department appeared with the item that the woman, Theresa Wilson,
title: After Fire Kills 3, Returning to Salvage Urn With Another Daughter's Ashes

body: A suspicious fire tore through a four-story building in Brooklyn on Monday evening, killing three people, two of them children, and seriously injuring another person, Fire Department officials said. The cause of the fire, at 1150 Putnam Avenue in Bushwick, was not immediately known, but Deputy Chief Stephen Moro said that it was being treated as
title: Suspicious Fire Kills 3 In Brooklyn Building

body: Until the mid-'70s, high-quality copper cookware was made in Brooklyn, by Bruno Waldrow. When he shut down no one in Brooklyn, and quite possibly the United States, was making classic copper pots. Mac Kohler, left, started Brooklyn Copper Cookware last year. He discovered that the Hammersmith company in Bushwick had acquired the Waldrow copper
title: FOOD STUFF; The Warm Glow of Copper, Made in Brooklyn

body: Let's begin with the mystery of the hidden bathroom. It's the summer of 2008. A young couple decides to buy an 800-square-foot apartment in a new condo building on the gentrifying outer edge of a fashionable Brooklyn neighborhood. The buyers go to close on the place, and as they're signing away half a million dollars, the building's developer,
title: The Supersizer of Brooklyn

body: The gold caps on his teeth are gone, as are the frenzied trappings of celebrity: the nonstop partying, the cars, the jewelry, the pet tiger, the liters of Cristal. Mike Tyson -- who was once addicted, by his own account, ''to everything'' -- now lives in what might be described as a controlled environment of his own making, a clean, well-lighted
title: 'I'VE LEARNED TO LIVE A BORING LIFE.'

body: The killing of Robert U. Martin in 1990 began with a fight over a gun lent for possible use in a murder. Mr. Martin, 30, had given a Mac-10 pistol to a younger man, Eric Williams, 19, but then decided that he wanted it back. The decision to collect the gun proved fatal for Mr. Martin. What began as a sidewalk scuffle between the two men at 2 a.m.
title: For Driver in Bronx Crash, Fight That Led to a Killing

body: Updated, 4:57 p.m. | The criminal case has been dropped against a 19-year-old Brooklyn woman who had faced up to two years in prison on charges of killing her little brother's hamster, after family members who witnessed the animal's death recanted their accounts, the authorities said. ''The family members that were witnesses to this are not really
title: Hamster-Killing Case Is Dropped

body: The trouble began, Theresa Smith said, shortly after she bought a hamster for her 9-year-old son. A few months later, the hamster, Princess Stephanie, was playing in its exercise ball on the floor of their apartment in Bushwick, Brooklyn, when an older son, who is 25, flew into a rage. ''He kicked it deliberately, the ball flew across the room, the
title: 19-Year-Old Is Charged In Killing of a Hamster

body: When David Campaniello and his partner, Will Levatino, came up with the idea of selling the breaded, golden, fried rice balls known as arancini three years ago, they headed to Sicily for research. The arancini there are ubiquitous and sometimes as ''large as grapefruits,'' as Mr. Campaniello put it. At Arancini Bros., the partners' new storefront
title: FOOD STUFF; Bushwick Looks More Sicilian With Arancini

body: An early-morning electrical fire in a home in Bushwick, Brooklyn, left two adults in serious condition on Monday, the Fire Department said. Neighbors watched in horror as flames engulfed the second floor of the two-story home on Bleecker Street near Myrtle Avenue just after 3 a.m. As smoke billowed out, two boys leaned out of the windows with small
title: Fire in Brooklyn House Seriously Injures 2 Residents

body: A column that celebrates drinking should pause every once in a while to celebrate not drinking, given that alcohol is a two-edged sword: catalyst for delight and engine of destruction; handled with restraint by some people, abused and best avoided entirely by others. It's a drug, with all the attendant dangers, and it's not the only way to
title: THE TIPSY DIARIES; Cocktails With a Twist: Zing but No Alcohol

body: On a brisk morning on Governors Island, as winter begins to surrender to spring, the fake palm trees that greet the ferry on Water Taxi Beach appear even more surreal than usual, poking up out of snow above the empty picnic tables. The ferry pulls in. The sun peeks through bare branches. A handful of people veer left toward the offices of the Trust
title: CITYROOM; Signs of Beautiful Isolation, and Even Spring, on a Walk on Governors Island

body: ON a recent blustery Friday night near McCarren Park in Brooklyn, Nayantara Banerjee, a k a the Williamsburg Seamster, was armored in a poncho sweater, knee-high snow boots from Urban Outfitters and a black-and silver-threaded scarf knotted over her long, jet-black hair. Despite the frigid air, Ms. Banerjee was happy to stretch her limbs. She had
title: Stitch by Stitch And Block by Block

body: Who says girls can't play football? Or that you don't go to Bushwick in Brooklyn to see a play? And if you think deconstructionist, experimental theater must be dry and dreary, the Half Straddle, an emerging troupe, has another surprise for you. ''In the Pony Palace/Football'' is a giddily exuberant confection that manages to conjure a
title: THEATER REVIEW | 'IN THE PONY PALACE/FOOTBALL'; Gender Blitz on a High School Gridiron

body: Along a freight train line that winds through Brooklyn and Queens, desolate areas are used as gathering spots or refuges for minor outlaws: graffiti painters, drug users and those who camp out with little more than a piece of cardboard, a blanket and a bottle of vodka to keep them company. In one spot, beneath an overpass on Ocean Avenue in
title: Beneath an Overpass, Hints of a Suspect's Obsession

body: THOUGH Anne Bauso grew up in Middle Village, Queens, she was always fond of Brooklyn. Her parents were from Bushwick, and on Saturdays she went there with her father and brother, visiting the extended family and shopping for food in the Italian section of Knickerbocker Avenue. ''I had very warm feelings for Brooklyn from the start,'' she said. Ms.
title: THE HUNT; A Move in the Direction of 'More Life'

author: E-mail: nocturnalist@nytimes.com
body: Things are often best when small; many find kittens infinitely preferable to cats, and sports cars preferable to minivans. And to Julian Velasco, curator of Brooklyn Botanic Garden's collection of 400-plus bonsai, his tiny spruces and minuscule maples are far superior to their sky-high siblings. When it comes to gala dinners, less is rarely more,
title: NOCTURNALIST; Tiny Trees, and a Meal in Miniature

title: Spare Times

body: It will be beautiful as it falls and magical as it dusts the ground, and seconds later, New York's next snowfall will be an urban nuisance, slipping your step, burying your car and lining your curbs with the slushie of doom. But when the snow comes -- and you know it will -- the people of 15 Central Park West will be ready. To clear the wide
title: CITY CRITIC; A Mere Shovel? Show the Snow Who's Boss

body: Russell K. Frederick began photographing the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn in 1999, shortly after he picked up a camera. ''When I told people where I lived, they would cringe, as if Bed-Stuy was this place where I had to wear a helmet and a bulletproof vest,'' Mr. Frederick said in an interview with James Estrin. ''They just assumed it to
title: From Bed-Stuyvesant, With Love

body: Eastern District, the name of this spacious new store, was what they once called the industrial area of Brooklyn encompassing parts of Greenpoint, Bushwick and Williamsburg, said Beth Lewand, who owns the store, along with her husband, Chris Gray. A former Polish butcher shop, it's lined with shelves and counters that feature about 50 cheeses and
title: FOOD STUFF; Try Not to Start Singing '100 Brands of Beer on the Wall'

body: All around Mirna B. López's modest one-bedroom apartment in Bushwick, Brooklyn, are reminders of God. ''I pray too much,'' said Ms. López, a Pentecostalist who is active in her church. In the kitchen, just above the stove, where Ms. López, 46, often cooks traditional Guatemalan dishes for her children, is a small, gold-colored bas-relief of the
title: THE NEEDIEST CASES; After What Seemed Like One Miracle, She Is Praying for Another

body: The steel gates on the Tortilleria Chinantla tortilla factory in Bushwick, Brooklyn, were drawn down on Monday morning, a telltale sign that something at the usually bustling seven-day-a-week plant was amiss. Juan Baten, a 22-year-old Guatemalan immigrant worker at the factory, died on the job earlier in the day after falling into a machine used to
title: Tortilla Factory Worker Falls Into a Dough Mixer and Dies

author: Jonah Weiner is the pop critic at Slate and a contributing editor at Rolling Stone. This is his first article for the magazine.
body: Brock Enright rents a studio in an old Catholic school in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, a former classroom that is hard to navigate without stepping on a drawing or kicking a sculpture, but he makes much of his art beyond his studio's walls -- in bars, fast-food joints, Chinatown shopping plazas, rooftops and other locations throughout Manhattan. One
title: If Your Life Were a Movie

body: A century ago, Israel Zangwill popular- ized the term in his play, ''The Melting Pot.'' From a Lower East Side rooftop, the protagonist proclaimed, ''What is the glory of Rome and Jerusalem, where all nations and races come to worship and look back, compared with the glory of America, where all races and nations come to labor and look forward?''New
title: Then as Now: New York's Shifting Ethnic Mosaic

body: Deerhoof This endearingly odd post-punk band has always made the most of incongruity, framing the girly-sweet singing of its bassist, Satomi Matsuzaki, against a crashing cacophony of guitar riffs and the slipperiest sort of rock drumming. ''Deerhoof vs. Evil,'' being released on Polyvinyl on Tuesday, adheres to this formula without succumbing to
title: PLAYLIST; Improvisatory Responses To Post-Punk Chirping

body: The cloth interior of her blue steel coffin will be custom-embroidered with the image of a firefighter in full gear, walking hand in hand with an angel. Her prayer cards will display her smiling face on one side and the words of the Fireman's Prayer on the other. And when mourners gather on Friday to say goodbye to Josephine B. Harris at a funeral
title: Funeral of a 9/11 Survivor Will Bring Out Firefighters

body: The story of her improbable rescue by New York City firefighters was among the most enduring to emanate from the horror of Sept. 11, 2001. It was told and retold: how a weary woman, Josephine Harris, was coaxed and carried to safety by six men from Ladder Company 6 in Chinatown who had rushed to the World Trade Center that morning. It was a feat of
title: Mourning A Woman Who Shared A 9/11 Escape

body: Charisma Massey and her friend did not feel threatened when a black car pulled up alongside them as they walked to the corner store in their Crown Heights, Brooklyn, neighborhood one day in October. Not until they heard the gunshots. The two girls ran, unharmed, and raced for home. Fortunately, the car did not follow. Charisma, 17, said she was
title: THE NEEDIEST CASES; Facing Gang Threats and Family Ills

body: FOR eight years, Brendan Mason had a great apartment in Clinton Hill, Brooklyn. His one-bedroom rental was in an owner-occupied brownstone with endless prewar charm. On the stoop one flight down, he would drink coffee, socialize with neighbors, have a smoke. His rent was less than $1,500 a month. His partner, Matthew Reuter, had a less compelling
title: THE HUNT; Room for Men to Work and for Astro to Play
